candidates.title: Typed event data + async event handlers

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: new feature or improvement to existing feature

labels.name: BREAKING CHANGE
labels.description: Breaking changes introduced in this PR

candidates.body:
Closes #241 and #506 

~~Async event handlers somehow do not type check yet.~~

This is a breaking change because closures now accept different types as arguments depending on the event used. This is also a breaking change because invalid event names are no longer allowed, and the event structs must be used explicitly when using the builder API.

candidates.title: Do not add values to the arena drop list if not necessary
Allow passing through attributes on components

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: new feature or improvement to existing feature

candidates.body:
This allows a component to take in a map of arguments so they can be passed through to an inner HTML element.
The current syntax proposal is the following:

# Passing attributes

Any prefixed "props" (`on:`, `bind:`) will be automatically passed through. For attributes that don't have a built in prefix, `attr:` can be added to pass it through.

## Example:
The class and on click event will be passed through via `Attributes`, `is_accessible` is a regular prop.
```rust
view! { cx, Label(attr:class = "bg-gray-400", on:click = on_click, is_accessible = true) { "Name" } }
```

# Applying attributes to elements

Applying will be done with Rust's "rest" operator.

## Example:
```rust
view! { cx, label(..attributes, id = aria_id) { (children) } }
```

# Example Use Case
[Accessible Checkbox](https://github.com/wingertge/headlessui-sycamore/blob/master/src/components/checkbox.rs)

# Current status

The code is very suboptimal and documentation will be added when the feature is done. The following parts of the feature are currently done:
- [x] The `Attribute` struct and `AttributeValue` enum required to pass through values in a type safe way
- [x] Parsing prefixed props as attributes and generating the `Attribute` struct from them
- [x] Applying attributes to an element
- [x] Tests
- [x] Cleanup and documentation
- [x] More ergonomic way to get values from `Attributes`
- [x] Example
- [x] Book documentation

candidates.title: Implement ToView manually for types

labels.name: BREAKING CHANGE
labels.description: Breaking changes introduced in this PR

candidates.body:
This lets us do some nice things such as:
```rust
let show = true;
view! { cx,
    (show.then(|| view! { cx, "Hello!" }))
}
```

**Breaking Changes:**
- `IntoView` renamed to `ToView` (which is more idiomatic in Rust)
- `IntoView::create` renamed to `ToView::to_view`
- Not all types that implement `Display` now implement `ToView`. For those types that used to implement `IntoView` but do not now implement `ToView`, a simple fix would be to just add a `to_string()` at the call-site.

candidates.title: (Runtime) Templates

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: new feature or improvement to existing feature

candidates.body:
Closes #19 

Adds a template system where `Template` represents the structure of the `view!` with holes inside. These holes can then be binded to and filled in with the dynamic values.

This should give a big performance boost on the client side because we are cloning templates now instead of creating each and every element individually.
This could also give a performance boost on server-side by allowing us to cache the SSR-ed strings.

This also unlocks other exciting features such as some form of hot view-reloading.
